Title: 42° Aniversario de la Sinfónica Simón Bolivar - Homenaje a Simón Díaz - Gustavo Dudamel
Description:
Homenaje a Simón Díaz con la Sinfónica Simón Bolívar, bajo la dirección de Gustavo Dudamel y la Coral Nacional Simón Bolívar, a cargo de Lourdes Sánchez. Concierto ofrecido el 9 de noviembre 2014 en la Sala Ríos Reyna del Teatro Teresa Carreño.

Repertorio: 
PAUL DESSENE. Hipnosis Mariposa.
Glosa Sinfónica sobre la Vaca Mariposa y el Becerrito (estreno mundial)

JUAN CARLOS NUÑEZ. Cinco tonadas de Simón Díaz 
• Mi querencia 
• Tonada del Cabrestero 
• Sabana 
• Garcita 
• Las espigas 
Intermedio 

ALEXANDER BERTI, Tonadas de Simón Díaz. 
• Tonada de luna llena 
• Mi querencia 
• El alcaraván 
• Sabana. Solista: Cristo Vassilaco

• Mercedes 
• La pena del becerrero 
• Pasaje del olvido 
• El loco Juan Carabina. Solistas: Jonas Yajure ( baritono) Marilyn Viloria ( Mezzo) Andrés Sulbarán (tenor)

Title: DUDAMEL & Simón Bolívar Orchestra - Live HD - Royal Festival Hall - BENZECRY: Rituales Amerindios /
Description:
London, Simón Bolívar Symphony Orchestra - Royal Festival Hall. Conductor: Gustavo Dudamel. Watch the full video of the concert here: http://bit.ly/MxxBLT (Video from The Southbank Centre) 26 June 2012. London Festival 2012 cultural olympiad. Live Concert HD -
Program:

"Rituales Amerindios" by Esteban BENZECRY: http://estebanbenzecry.com/ 

Pre-Columbian Triptych for Orchestra (2008) Commissioned by Gothenburg Symphony Orchestra
00:09 I -- Ehécatl (Azteca wind god) 
10:35 II -- Chaac (Maya water god) 
20:20 III -- Illapa (Inca thunderclap god)

Esteban Benzecry: Rituales Amerindios (29m) 
Richard Strauss: An Alpine Symphony (53m)

The two pieces in this concert are both celebrations of nature on a huge orchestral canvas. They are separated by a century, and written by composers who, themselves, were born a century apart (Esteban Benzecry, born 1970 and Richard Strauss, born 1864).
Although Dudamel and his orchestra have triumphantly made the mainstream European classical repertoire their own, they are also passionate champions of music by South American composers. The motivation behind Benzecry's Rituales Amerindios (American Indian Rituals) is, in the Argentinian composer's words, "my wish to write something that would represent the three great pre-Columbian Latin-American cultures - the Aztec (in Mexico), the Mayan (in Southern Mexico and Central America) and Inca (mostly in Peru)."
In this 28-minute piece divided into three movements,. Benzecry skillfully uses the colours in his giant orchestra to depict nature, water, evocations of forests, thunder, as well as ritualistic dances. The opening movement is dedicated to Ehecati, the Aztec god of the wind. We hear a fanfare-type flourish which will turn up again in different guises in the other two movements. Chaac, the Mayan water god, inspires the second slow movement of the work, full of liquid percussion, including slides upwards on timpani, low marimba sounds and the miraculous noise of the rain-stick. Things get moving again in the last movement, with an evocation of the Inca thunder God Illapa: a storm gathers, rushing up through the orchestra which, this being Latin music, inevitably transforms itself into a dance.

25-minute interval

Richard Strauss: An Alpine Symphony

Title: Dudamel: Ravel - Daphnis et Chloé: Suite No. 2 (Orquesta Sinfónica Simón Bolívar Orchestra) | (4/7)
Description:
From the Lucerne Festival at Easter 2007,
Orquesta Sinfónica de la Juventud Venezolana Simón Bolívar, under the baton of Gustavo Dudamel, performs works by Maurice Ravel, Leonard Bernstein, Arturo Marquez, Silvestre Revueltas and Alberto Ginastera. Part 4 of 7.

Watch the full concert playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLBjoEdEVMABKVE9Ae2cm5Q6AD9IwdTsE3
Subscribe to EuroArts: https://goo.gl/jrui3M

Maurice Ravel - Daphnis et Chloé: Suite No. 2

Gustavo Dudamel - conductor
Orquesta Sinfónica Simón Bolívar de Venezuela
(formerly known as Orquesta Sinfónica de la Juventud Venezolana Simón Bolívar)

About the concert

For several years now, Gustavo Dudamel and the young musicians from the Venezuelan youth 
orchestra "Simón Bolívar" have been causing a furor on the international music scene. More than 
anything else, it is they who have earned the Venezuelan orchestra system respect around the 
world: 30 years ago, the conductor, composer and economist José Antonio Abreu had the vision 
of combining social work and classical music. Abreu's goal was to tear down elitist structures in 
music education and make music a fundamental right of all the country's children.

2007, EuroArts, in co-operation with ZDF/Arte

X/ Twitter: https://twitter.com/GustavoDudamel 
Facebook: https://web.facebook.com/GDudamel 

Gustavo Dudamel: The Maestro Who’s Changing Classical Music

Gustavo Dudamel is one of today’s most influential conductors, known for his electrifying performances and commitment to music education. As Music & Artistic Director of the LA Philharmonic and Simón Bolívar Symphony Orchestra of Venezuela, and soon the New York Philharmonic, he is redefining what classical music can be.

Shaped by El Sistema, Venezuela’s revolutionary music program, Dudamel believes in music’s power to transform lives. He co-founded YOLA (Youth Orchestra Los Angeles) and the Dudamel Foundation to expand access to music education worldwide.

Dudamel’s innovative programming has earned the LA Phil the title of "the most important orchestra in America" (NY Times). His award-winning recordings feature Mahler, Beethoven, and Latin American composers, earning him five Grammy Awards. He has conducted the Vienna Philharmonic’s New Year’s Concert, composed film scores (West Side Story), and collaborated with artists such as Billie Eilish, Coldplay, and Christina Aguilera.

#gustavodudamel

Title: Gustavo Dudamel and LA Phil Live At Tynecastle | Edinburgh International Festival 2019
Description:
Gustavo Dudamel and the LA Philharmonic head to Scotland to open the 2019 Edinburgh International Festival, with a concert at Tynecastle Park that celebrates the Golden Age of Hollywood, featuring iconic themes by John Williams, Bernard Herrmann, Henry Mancini and more! This Opening Event of the 2019 Edinburgh International Festival will be livestreamed on Gustavo's YouTube at 7:00 BST.

Title: Gustavo Dudamel | London Festival 2012 cultural olympiad: "Rituales Amerindios" by Esteban BENZECRY
Description:
Simón Bolívar Symphony Orchestra, Conductor: Gustavo Dudamel - Royal Festival Hall, London. Live Streaming from The Southbank Centre, 26 June 2012. London Festival 2012 cultural olympiad. 
"RITUALES AMERINDIOS" by Esteban BENZECRY: http://estebanbenzecry.com/ 
Pre-Columbian Triptych for Orchestra (2008) Commissioned by Gothenburg Symphony Orchestra
00:01 I -- Ehécatl (Azteca wind god) 
10:30 II -- Chaac (Maya water god) 
20:13 III -- Illapa (Inca thunderclap god)

Written in 2008 and commissioned by a Goteborg Symphony Orchestra (The National Sweden’s Orchestra), is dedicated to Gustavo Dudamel, and this fact motivated me to write something tha would represent the three great latines pre-columbians cultures: the Azteca (in Mexico), Maya (in South of Mexico and Central America) and Inca (South America - most in Peru).
These three works, that conform the Tryptic can be performed separately as independent works.
The composer do not pretends to do ethnomusicology, but to take roots, rhytms and mythology as inspiration to develop his own musical language in a kind of imaginary folklore. This work was completed with the support of the John Guggenheim Fellowship for Music and premiered the 13th and 15th january 2010 in Gothenburg and performed in the XXVI Canary Island Music Festival (Spain).

I – Ehécatl ( Azteca wind god)
In Azteca’s mythology and for others cultures in Central America, Ehécatl was the wind’s god. Usually is interpretated as a manifestation of Quetzatcoatl, the sacred feathered serpent, wifh the name of Ehécatl- Quetzalcoatl, which appears in the breathing of the living beens and in the breeze, that comes with the clouds, giving rain into the cultivates lands
.He is one of the principals gods of the cosmogonie and a appreciated hero in the world’s mythical creation.
Sometimes, he is associated with all the Cardinal directions since the winds blows in all directionsThe music begins with a fanfare that announces the arrival of Ehecatl, the Azteca wind god, with winds that blows faster and faster and violents, to arrive to a B part, more calm, that will us to think that we are in the hurricane’s eye, but after, little by little, will the winds becomo more intenses, earing a distant quotation of the Ehecatl’s fanfare, finally to disolve the storm and to disappear Ehecatl.
This movement is conceived as the passage of a hurricane, what is compatible with the musical form ABA, even if the second A is not texural but in spirit
It is not programmatic music, the composer looks for to find the ethereal essence and multiform quality of the wind, benefactor or destroyer, using for that an orchestration who takes sonorities from the most diverses system, without to be tied to any in particular, as tonal procedures, atonalism, pentatonic scales, minimalism, spectralism, multiphonics (in the woodwinds) and sonorities from the electronic music.

II – Chaac (Maya water god)
Chaac was the rain’s god, and also of the fertility.
He was a very important god, symbol of the creating energy, because that Chaac is related with the importance of to learn to canalize wisely our creating energies.
We must find the maya’s simbology: if the water is the symbol of the life in the planet, Inside each human been, the water is the energy who brought into life.
Chaac was also considered to be divided into four equal entities. Each division represented the North, South, Est and West.
The water god, with his fecundity energy is taken in the beginning of the movement as drops, till appears in the central part in a powerful tide, that contains the Ehecatl’s fanfare.
The musical proceedings is based in clusters, that gives a base a little motifs melodics or rhytmics of imaginary folklore of the Mayas, inside a mysterious atmosphere submerged in the jungle sounds.

III – Illapa (Inca thunderclap god)
Symbolized by the Illapa serpent, he was the god of the weather, and one of the most popular between the gods.
His name means lightning and thunder. It was a believe that he can to rain from the Galaxy, with water from a pitcher.
The movement starts with a baguala’s rhythm (song of prey and protest), that along with motifs of imaginary folklore Inca, will appears as an invocation to the thunderclap god, to obtain the benefits of the rain, that always goes with him. After that arrives a Scherzo-Carnavalito (joyful rhythm of dance that means Little Carnival), for finally and taking proceedings of the electronic music, translated into the symphony orchestra, for to end in a frantic “rain’s dance” with a great rhythmical power.

#GustavoDudamel #EstebanBenzecry #SimónBolívarOrchestra #RoyalFestivalHall  #ElSistema #Musicaargentina #Compositorargentino #RitualesAmerindios #OperadeParis #OperaNationalDeParis #LaPhil #LosAngelesPhilharmonic #NewYorkPhilharmonic #NYPhil #TeatroColon #CarnegieHall #MariaValverde #ArturoMarquez #Danzon Opera National de Paris #AlbertoGinastera #FranceMusique #BerlinerPhilharmoniker

20:13 III -- Illapa (Inca thunderclap god)

Written in 2008 and commissioned by a Goteborg Symphony Orchestra (The National Sweden’s Orchestra), is dedicated to Gustavo Dudamel, and this fact motivated me to write something tha would represent the three great latines pre-columbians cultures: the Azteca (in Mexico), Maya (in South of Mexico and Central America) and Inca (South America - most in Peru).
These three works, that conform the Tryptic can be performed separately as independent works.
The composer do not pretends to do ethnomusicology, but to take roots, rhytms and mythology as inspiration to develop his own musical language in a kind of imaginary folklore. This work was completed with the support of the John Guggenheim Fellowship for Music and premiered the 13th and 15th january 2010 in Gothenburg and performed in the XXVI Canary Island Music Festival (Spain).
I – Ehécatl ( Azteca wind god)
In Azteca’s mythology and for others cultures in Central America, Ehécatl was the wind’s god. Usually is interpretated as a manifestation of Quetzatcoatl, the sacred feathered serpent, wifh the name of Ehécatl- Quetzalcoatl, which appears in the breathing of the living beens and in the breeze, that comes with the clouds, giving rain into the cultivates lands
.He is one of the principals gods of the cosmogonie and a appreciated hero in the world’s mythical creation.
Sometimes, he is associated with all the Cardinal directions since the winds blows in all directionsThe music begins with a fanfare that announces the arrival of Ehecatl, the Azteca wind god, with winds that blows faster and faster and violents, to arrive to a B part, more calm, that will us to think that we are in the hurricane’s eye, but after, little by little, will the winds becomo more intenses, earing a distant quotation of the Ehecatl’s fanfare, finally to disolve the storm and to disappear Ehecatl.
This movement is conceived as the passage of a hurricane, what is compatible with the musical form ABA, even if the second A is not texural but in spirit
It is not programmatic music, the composer looks for to find the ethereal essence and multiform quality of the wind, benefactor or destroyer, using for that an orchestration who takes sonorities from the most diverses system, without to be tied to any in particular, as tonal procedures, atonalism, pentatonic scales, minimalism, spectralism, multiphonics (in the woodwinds) and sonorities from the electronic music.

II – Chaac (Maya water god)
Chaac was the rain’s god, and also of the fertility.
He was a very important god, symbol of the creating energy, because that Chaac is related with the importance of to learn to canalize wisely our creating energies.
We must find the maya’s simbology: if the water is the symbol of the life in the planet, Inside each human been, the water is the energy who brought into life.
Chaac was also considered to be divided into four equal entities. Each division represented the North, South, Est and West.
The water god, with his fecundity energy is taken in the beginning of the movement as drops, till appears in the central part in a powerful tide, that contains the Ehecatl’s fanfare.
The musical proceedings is based in clusters, that gives a base a little motifs melodics or rhytmics of imaginary folklore of the Mayas, inside a mysterious atmosphere submerged in the jungle sounds.

III – Illapa (Inca thunderclap god)
Symbolized by the Illapa serpent, he was the god of the weather, and one of the most popular between the gods.
His name means lightning and thunder. It was a believe that he can to rain from the Galaxy, with water from a pitcher.
The movement starts with a baguala’s rhythm (song of prey and protest), that along with motifs of imaginary folklore Inca, will appears as an invocation to the thunderclap god, to obtain the benefits of the rain, that always goes with him. After that arrives a Scherzo-Carnavalito (joyful rhythm of dance that means Little Carnival), for finally and taking proceedings of the electronic music, translated into the symphony orchestra, for to end in a frantic “rain’s dance” with a great rhythmical power.

Title: Gustavo Dudamel | Piano Concerto « Universos Infinitos » by Esteban BENZECRY | Sergio Tiempo, piano.
Description:
Piano Concerto « Universos Infinitos » by Esteban BENZECRY
02:11 I - UN MUNDO INTERIOR
14:34 II - ÑUQUE CUYEN (Madre Luna)
26:31 III - TOCCATA WILLKA KUTI (Retorno del Sol)
Commentary: https://www.estebanbenzecry.com/obra/universos-infinitos-piano-concerto/

Broadcasted on May 3, 2020 at Radio KUSC https://www.kusc.org/radio/on-demand/socal-sunday-night-on-demand/  
Recorded live in concert at Walt Disney Concert hall on Oct 12 & 13, 2019
Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra
Gustavo Dudamel, Conductor.
Sergio Tiempo, Piano.

Reviews & Interviews: 
Bachtrack (Review): By David Wolfson 

Dudamel leads New York Philharmonic in spectacular new piano concerto.

 "..This is an absolutely outstanding composition, undoubtedly the most engaging and satisfying new piano concerto I have heard from a living composer.." https://bachtrack.com/fr_FR/review-dudamel-tiempo-benzecry-dvorak-new-york-philharmonic-january-2020 

Los Angeles Times (Review): By Mark Swed 

"...The concerto is dedicated to the virtuoso Venezuelan pianist Sergio Tiempo, who played it from memory, which seemed an impossibility. A catapulting Tiempo almost never stops for 30 minutes. The Steinway is subject to all you might ever want to subject it to. Phenomenal runs. Tone clusters banged out with the elbows. Percussive playing of the strings inside the instrument. Tiempo somehow made the impossible possible...." https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/story/2019-10-11/dudamel-music-from-americas?

The New York Times (Review): By Anthony Tommasini 

"..This varied program opened with Ives and included the New York premiere of a colorfully eclectic piano concerto by Esteban Benzecry..." "...The music itself was colorfully orchestrated, restless and likable..." "...The first movement is run through with an assertive four-note theme, like a somber fanfare. I heard echoes of Prokofiev and Messiaen in the piano part, full of pounding rhythms, cascading chords, spiraling swirls of fast notes, and that four-note theme, played in every contortion. The mercurial, mysterious slow movement was the strongest music, with intriguing cluster chords in the piano and shimmering, eerie orchestra sonorities. The finale is a dizzying perpetual-motion toccata. Mr. Tiempo gave a scintillating and virtuosic performance..." https://www.nytimes.com/2020/01/16/arts/music/gustavo-dudamel-philharmonic-review.html


New York Classical (Review): By Eric C. Simpson .
Argentine premiere tops Czech standby in Dudamel’s Philharmonic visit. 

"....The evening’s most rewarding item was the New York premiere of Universos infinitos, a piano concerto by Esteban Benzecry..." https://newyorkclassicalreview.com/2020/01/argentine-premiere-tops-czech-standby-in-dudamels-philharmonic-visit/
 Opera World (Review): by Carlos Javier López El huracán Dudamel arrasa en Nueva York "...una obra que está destinada a una larga vida..." https://www.operaworld.es/el-huracan-dudamel-arrasa-en-nueva-york/
  
San Francisco classical Voice (Review): 
Gustavo Dudamel and Pianist Sergio Tiempo Ignite Esteban Benzecry’s Universos infinitos By Jim Farber 

“..It’s a work that deserves a place in the contemporary repertory, though it’s hard to imagine anyone other than Tiempo being able to display its full range of fierce, take-no-prisoners dynamics…” https://www.sfcv.org/reviews/los-angeles-philharmonic/gustavo-dudamel-and-pianist-sergio-tiempo-ignite-esteban-benzecrys

PLAYBILL (Interview): Dudamel Leads New York Philharmonic With Spotlight on Latin American Talent By David Masello 

His concerts will feature the New York premiere of Universos infinitos, a piano concerto by Argentinean composer Esteban Benzecry, January 15–21. http://www.playbill.com/article/dudamel-leads-new-york-philharmonic-with-spotlight-on-latin-american-talent

Cultural Ataché (Interview): By Craig L. Byrd 
The Infinite Universe of Composer Esteban Benzecry And the long-awaited premiere of his piano concerto 
https://culturalattache.co/2019/10/09/the-infinite-universe-of-composer-esteban-benzecry/?

Title: MAURICE RAVEL - Bolero
Description: GUSTAVO DUDAMEL CONDUCTS WIENER PHILHARMONIKER

Title: Maurice Ravel - Bolero / Gustavo Dudamel conducts the Wiener Philharmoniker at Lucerne Festival 2010
Description:
At the closing concert of the Lucerne Festival 2010, the Wiener Philharmoniker performed Maurice Ravel's probably most famous piece of music under the baton of Gustavo Dudamel: Boléro.

The concert was broadcast live in more than 50 cinemas in Europe on 18 September 2010.

Recording Date: 18 September 2010
Composers: Maurice Ravel
Orchestras: Wiener Philharmoniker
Conductors: Gustavo Dudamel
Director: Michael Beyer

Title: Sinfonía No. 9, Ludwig van Beethoven - Gustavo Dudamel - OSSBV - CNSB
Description: Los cantos de amistad y libertad que forman parte de la Novena Sinfonía “Coral” de Ludwig van Beethoven bajo la dirección del maestro Gustavo Dudamel, quien una vez más logró unificar en un sentimiento común de confraternidad a los artistas participantes. Bajo su batuta, la Sinfónica Simón Bolívar de Venezuela, la Coral Nacional Simón Bolívar  y los solistas Ámbar Arias, soprano, Marilyn Viloria, mezzosoprano, Jesús Herrera, tenor y Jonás Yajure, barítono ofrecieron un concierto memorable, que podrá ser revivido a través de esta nueva conexión.

Title: Sinfonía N° 6 "Patética" de Piotr Ilich Tchaikovsky - Gustavo Dudamel - Sinfónica Simón Bolívar
Description: Sinfonía No. 6 en Si menor, opus 74 de Piotr Illich Tchaikovsky, “La Patética”, ejecutada por la Sinfónica Simón Bolívar, bajo la batuta del maestro Gustavo Dudamel, en concierto ofrecido por el 39 aniversario en la Sala Simón Bolívar del Centro Nacional de Acción Social por la Música, el 16 de febrero de 2014.

Title: Tchaikovsky piano concerto 1 with Gustavo Dudamel and Sergio Tiempo 2005
Description: Live from the Inaugural concert of the Martha Argerich Festival in Buenos Aires 2005, soloist Sergio Tiempo plays with Gustavo Dudamel and the Bolivar Orchestra, Tchaikovsky's piano concerto number 1.

Title: William Shakespeare - Hamlet - La Tempestad - Romeo y Julieta - Tchaikovsky - Gustavo Dudamel
Description: La Orquesta Sinfónica Simón Bolívar de Venezuela, Gustavo Dudamel y el actor Luigi Sciamanna interpretan La Tempestad, Fantasía Sinfónica, Op. 18, y las oberturas Romeo y Julieta y Hamlet, con textos del escritor inglés William Shakespeare, en los que se inspiró Tchaikovsky. Fue un concierto del 9 de febrero del año 2014, y corresponde a la programación de conciertos por el 39 aniversario de El Sistema.
